Award.AwardTitle: DCL: HBCU:EAGER- Study of Biological Interaction between Fungal Cells and Electrospun Nanofibrous Platform

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
DCL; HBCU EAGER: Structural and functional characterization of proteins associated with silver nanoparticle resistant Escherichia coli

In recent years, integration of electrospun nanofibers in commercial products has been growing exponentially. Electrospun nanofibers have been found in a number of applications such as air filtration, liquid filtration, performance apparel, drug delivery, scaffold for tissue engineering, battery separators and etc. The electrospun nanofibers are already exposed (and will continue being exposed) to our environment through corresponding commercial products in the form of nano fibrous mat. Inevitably, they will be in contact with microorganisms in environment, including fungi. However, little is known about biological interaction between electrospun nanofibrous mat and fungal cells. Detailed interaction information between fungal cells and electrospun nanofibrous mat from this research project will create public awareness about electrospun nanofibers' uses and their impact on environmental microorganism. Policy makers can also make use of the information to regulate the integration of electrospun nanofibers in consumer products.

The objective of this research is to explore viability and growth behavior of a model fungal cell (yeast) on electrospun polyacrylonitrile nano fibrous mat (as well as other electrospun nano fibrous mats) by cell morphology, cell number, and cell metabolic activity. The results will be compared with those from microfibrous and film counterparts. The project will provide new knowledge regarding interaction between fungal cells and electrospun nanofibrous materials by investigating the effect of chemical structure, size, surface roughness, hierarchical structure of the electrospun nanofibrous mats. The research outcomes can aid in understanding the mechanism of the biological interaction and disclose a brand-new way to realize antifungal functionality by simple physical contact without integrating any antifungal drugs or functional groups. The acquired knowledge will fill in a largely unknown research field and further translate to other nano materials that have similar structure, dimension, and/or morphology as electrospun nanofibrous materials.

Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nanomaterial-processing technique of electrospinning provides a unique and straightforward way to produce continuous fibers at submicrometer and nanometer scale, which is at least one order of magnitude smaller than conventional fibers. Integration of electrospun nanofibrous mat in commercial products has been growing exponentially and electrospun nanofibers have already been exposed to our environment. However, impacts of electrospun nanofibers on both environment and human being have not been thoroughly addressed and little is known about biological interaction between environmental microorganism and electrospun nanofibers.

This EAGER project explored viability and growth behavior of model fungal cells (two yeast strains SK1 and Candida albicans) on electrospun nanofibrous mat (three materials: polyacrylonitrile (PAN), cellulose acetate (CA) and cellulose). The results were compared with those from microfibrous and film counterparts. The results indicated that electrospun PAN and CA nanofibrous mats have inhibition effect on the growth of yeast cells. The effects of varied PAN nanofiber morphology (size, alignment, and surface roughness) on the yeast cell growth were further studied. Smaller fiber size, random fiber alignment, rough fiber surface with negative curvature demonstrated more inhibition effect.

The research result provided new knowledge to understand biological interaction between fungal cells and electrospun nanofibrous mat and partially filled in a largely unknow research field. This research project revealed a brand-new potential to develop materials with antifungal functionality.

The research outcome has been disseminated to scientific/local community six times in regional, national and international professional conferences and integrated in the Nanomaterial course which the PI is teaching every year. The research project resulted in one peer-reviewed journal article and trained and partially supported three Ph.D. students in Nanoengineering Graduate Program at North Carolina A&T State University, the largest public HBCU in the nation. The project has created public awareness on uses of electrospun nanofibers and their impact on environmental microorganisms.


Last Modified: 04/29/2020
Modified by: Lifeng Zhang

Smaller fiber size, random fiber alignment, rough fiber surface with negative curvature demonstrated more inhibition effect.
